data.status: Strategy underwent public consultation at the end of 2019 - a consultation report has been reviewed by the CEC and 'approved' at Council meeting 5.5.20 (Minutes: "...approves the draft Environment Strategy, following public consultation").
data.well_presented: Standalone document with some introduction to the context
data.baseline_analysis: The report and summary report refer to analysis without a source/link (so less transparency and credibility), quote: "The current carbon footprint of the Council has been assessed... [followed by numbers, but no explanation of analysis, no methodology, no source/link]
data.plan_due: No clear mention or commitment to a 'plan/action plan' on the back of this strategy. Instead, the CE Council signposts to its separate, pre-existing Green Infrastructure Plan (while also referencing other pieces such as the UK Gov's centralised 25 year plan on Environment. For reference, here is the local CEC Green Infrastructure plan page: https://www.cheshireeast.gov.uk/planning/spatial_planning/research_and_evidence/green_infrastructure_framework.aspx

data.status: Draft. Still only a draft after 12 months; approved by the Cabinet in March 2020, but that means little (the whole council declared an emergency in March 2019).
data.well_presented: No, the papers for the Cabinet meeting (plus its two appendices) need to be processed via the council's PR dept in order to make make it glossy and appear impressive for public consumption.
data.baseline_analysis: Haringey has been publishing annual carbon reports for some years. The goal of reducing carbon emissions Borough-wide was quietly dropped and replaced by the far smaller goal of reducing emissions from council-owned buildings. Thus, any sale of council buildings would flatter their figures. The council claims that they will meet their goal—"40:20" of several years ago—of achieving a 40% reduction in emissions by 2020. (if this is true, then it is true for council buildings only).
data.notes:
Haringey's "action plan" is admitted to be only a draft. It re-states the importance of the issue and talks at length about the council's ambition. It is three months overdue and comes 12 months after the council unanimously declared a Climate Emergency (in March 2019). There is no action in the plan. There will be no action before November 2020 at the earliest. In any event, it is moot as to whether the current Administration is capable of undertaking any action after then (i.e. after COP26).

Haringey did produce an impressive document setting out their ambitions, "Going Green: Haringey’s Greenest Borough Strategy". The difficulty is that this was published 11 (eleven) years ago: http://opinion8.ning.com/forum/topics/climate-change-and-haringey-council
data.plan_due: No earlier than November 2020. Although the PR function is likely to produce publications saying how well the council is doing, it is unlikely Haringey will take meaningful action.
data.title: Briefing: Haringey Climate Change Action Plan
Haringey Climate Change Action Plan – A Route Map for a Net Zero Carbon Haringey
Haringey Climate Change Action Plan – A Route Map for a Net Zero Carbon Haringey

data.notes: https://climatescience.blogspot.com/2019/09/no-climate-emergency-recommended-in-new.html "Whilst the Panel recognises that other Councils have declared a climate emergency, this Council can achieve more on a local level through the development of an environment action plan, with the ambition of achieving a carbon neutral position for the New Forest District Council by 2050.  Once developed, the action plan should give prominence within the Council’s Corporate Plan to ensure that environmental issues, including climate change, are taken into account in future decision making."
